article.headline: âThanks a lot, COVID!â Bummed-out boomers feel cheated out of retirement years
article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NextAvenue.org. It is part ofÂ The Coronavirus Outbreak: What You Need To Know Special Report âThese are supposed to be the best years of my life,â says Matt, 64, an account manager for a telecom company in the suburbs of Denver (he prefers not to include his last name for this story). âIâve been working like a dog for decades, got the kids through college, then saw my marriage fizzle. Now here I am, almost ready to retire, buy the convertible and start dating with a vengeance, and itâs all going up in smoke. Thanks a lot, COVID!â This ire is going around as some boomers see their anticipated next stage of life evaporate asÂ the pandemicÂ continues to have the globe in its grip. Of course, those lucky enough to escape the virus are very grateful for their good health. But as the days, weeks, months and now seasons of being on âpauseâ unfurl, many of those at midlife and later have had it up to here â and then some. Feelings of frustration and even anger can be hard to overcome if your âprime timeâ gets twisted like a pretzel. A key factor: Time is of the essence. âThe pandemic has brought about a lot of disappointment and changes. Many boomers may feel cheated as expectations for these years and retirement have been upended,â says Caroline Atterton, lead therapist for the senior intensive outpatient program at San Diegoâs Sharp Mesa Vista Hospital. âBecause the time ahead is limited, there may be a sense of urgency about the need âto get on with itâ and do those things that the pre-retirement years made it difficult to do. COVID-19 forces them into a sedentary lifestyle that contradicts those plans.â “ I have a friend, Tosia, whoâs a Holocaust survivor now in her 90s. I think what she saw â gunfire, bombs, fires, murder â is worse than staying inside due to coronavirus. Comparatively speaking, this pandemic is perhaps not as horrible. And this too shall end.â ” â Dr. Melvin Konner, professor of anthropology, neuroscience and behavioral biology at Emory University This sense of now or never even has a name. âAround midlife, we experience whatâs known as a âshift in time perspective,â which means we begin to think about the time we have between this moment and the end of life. We start to realize that life is finite and that opportunities for a do-over are less likely,â explains Suzanne Degges-White, author and chair of the department of counseling and higher education at the College of Education, Northern Illinois University.Loss of family time and togetherness At this age, a personâs hopes and plans may be treasured, whether they involveÂ bucket-list travelÂ or favorite Friday-night plans. Flora Hanft, of Long Island, loved the life she had constructed pre-COVID-19, and misses activities like visits to local art galleries with her husband. As she says, âNow my days are all the same and â like my COVID outfits â shapeless.â For others, the most angst-ridden aspect to the pandemic is the loss of family time and togetherness as the generations grow. âI was so excited for the arrival of my first grandchild,â says Dr. Sharon Wager, a geriatric and hospice physician who lives near Houston. âKinsley was born on February 12, and maybe two weeks later, I had my first COVID-19 patient. I felt unsafe personally and worried about spreading the virus,â she says. âI didnât see my new granddaughter until June, and then from a distance â no hugging, no kissing.Â I want to hold and snuggle my own sweet grandchild.Â I feel as if being a part of Kinsleyâs early life has been stolen from me.âSampling an isolated life While the coronavirus has deeply altered the way all people are living, itâs dealt some in the older generation an especially ferocious wallop. If youâre over 50, you know the fear some younger people have of being within a mile of you. No one wants to be the âvirus vectorâ that lands you in the hospital. Also see: We want a diverse area with moderate population, warm, beach and culture â so where should we retire? Many,Â manyÂ boomers have received pleading phone calls from their adult children begging them to stay inside 24/7, for fear that they may contract COVID-19 and have it prove fatal. âI might as well be a hundred and four versus my real age of 64,â says Matt. âI almost never leave the house.â Boomers have been contemplating the joys of continuing their illusion of agelessness, says Hanft. âThe virus doesnât just restrict their freedom and dreams, but it has codified ageism by calling out that boomers are in the high-risk group,â she notes. âThis sets back decades of baseball-cap-wearing age denial.âDealing with the disappointment The pandemic also amplifies another crummy aspect of growing older: The feeling that youâre no longer in full command. âAging can bring a lot of new challenges that are not always expected,â says Atterton. âIt can be difficult to cope when things do not always turn out as we had planned. This gives rise to feelings of not being in control, which is a source of anxiety.â COVID-19 has intensified that exponentially: An invisible enemy is lurking out there and could strike at any moment. If that doesnât rob people of their sense of agency, what would? In this situation, denial is not your friend: Distracting yourself from the core issue wonât work (try as you may to watch every possible procedural drama on Netflix NFLX, +1.43% Â ). âItâs important to acknowledge and understand oneâs feelings. It makes sense to feel hurt, sad, or cheated. The more one minimizes or pushes these emotions away, the more those unresolved feelings will impact how we feel about ourselves and how we behave,â explains Atterton. âWe might think, âThis is never going to endâ or âThings will never be as they once were,â making it difficult to see other alternatives.â So. Step One is to check in with yourself and accept that, yes, this is a really,Â reallyÂ bad moment thatâs derailing your plans. Sit with that and stop trying to push it away.Try three little words: âcompared to what?â Dr. Melvin Konner, the Samuel Candler Dobbs professor of anthropology and of neuroscience and behavioral biology at Emory University, says that â next to âI love youâ â the most important words we can use in this life are: âCompared to what?â Yes, things may be terrible, but frame it in terms of what past generations have experienced; there is always hardship. âUnlike our parentsâ generation, we didnât live through the Great Depression, nor did we fight fascism to make sure democracy had a future. I have a friend, Tosia, whoâs a Holocaust survivor now in her 90s,â Konner says. âI think what she saw â gunfire, bombs, fires, murder â is worse than staying inside due to coronavirus. Comparatively speaking, this pandemic is perhaps not as horrible. And this too shall end.â Read: Social Security missteps could push millions of elderly Americans into poverty If youâre close to someone who is bemoaning their âcheatedâ status, you can help them re-spin that viewpoint with this technique from Degges-White: âWhen someone is doing a âYes, butâ response, such as, âYes, I could use Zoom ZM, +2.89% Â , but thatâs not the same,â they should be met with a âYes, butâ that counters their perspective: âYes, Zoom isnât the same, butÂ itâs a great way to hear and see your grandchildren,â or âYes, itâs lonely not being able to visit friends, but itâs important that you not only care for your own health, but that of others, too.â Or try it on yourself as a self-talk trick.Donât wallow in frustration Atterton suggests giving yourself some vigorous pep talks when cries of âUnfair!â well up inside you. âWe can practice self-compassion. Be gentle with yourself and cheer yourself on! Tell yourself, âI am taking good care of myself during this difficult time. Even though things are not right now, I am going to get through this,ââ she says. âOne can also treat the pandemic as an opportunity. Now is the time to learn something new â a new language or yoga â or read more.â Atterton also advises people to stay social, even though we must physically distance. âPhone or FaceTime with friends and family,â she advises. âRemember, loneliness and depression in older adults go hand-in-hand. Relationships are of paramount importance here. They lead to increased physical and emotional well-being and improved quality of life.â Wager has found that while technology is no substitute for cradling her granddaughter, it does allow for easy contact. âMy daughter and I use the Alexa and Tinybeans apps to keep close,â she says. Digital tools are also a source of connection for Hanft, who misses her art gallery outings. âI am wonkily drawn toÂ virtual museum tours. The technology is getting better, and you can have a glass of wine during the tour â in my case, a Kir â rather than in the overpriced cafe afterwards,â she says. âAnd I love the virtual piano concertsÂ our friend Michael GarinÂ is doing via Facebook FB, +0.26% Â twice a week.â Also see: Americansâ love affair with pickup trucks might be derailing their retirement plansChin up for the younger ones Thinking of others will also help defuse the full brunt of COVID-19 frustration. âAs angry as I am about what COVID has done to my life,â says Matt, âI feel worse for my kids who are just launching their adult lives. I try to be very encouraging when talking to them. I had the freewheeling fun days that they are missing. It feels good to step out of my anger and support them.â Konner echoes that as well. Having just turned 74, he says he is glad he is still teaching: âThough there are things I would love to do in retirement, I am glad I am connected to young people â they need us to give them perspective, to help them know that their lives will get back on track. I like to remind them if they do the right thing now, one day soon theyâll be telling stories about surviving the pandemic of 2020.â Donât all of us look forward to those bragging rights? Janet Siroto is an NYC-based journalist and content strategist who specializes in lifestyle, wellness and consumer-trend topics, as well as personal essays.
